"Water-repelling shields.<[silence:1000]> Nature’s trick for staying dry."
<[silence:2400]>
The word hydrophobic comes from Greek: hydro (water) + phobos (fear).<[silence:1200]> It describes surfaces that push water away, like a duck’s back or a freshly waxed car.<[silence:2400]

Most materials let water spread or soak in.<[silence:1200]> But hydrophobic surfaces trap tiny air pockets in their texture—like a bed of nails for droplets.<[silence:1200]> Water can’t grip, so it beads up and rolls off.<[silence:2400]

The lotus leaf is the classic example.<[silence:1200]> Its bumpy surface, covered in waxy crystals, forces raindrops to cleanse dirt as they slide.<[silence:1200]> Scientists copied this for self-cleaning paints and stain-resistant fabrics.<[silence:2400]

Extreme versions, called superhydrophobic, make water bounce like a rubber ball.<[silence:1200]> A droplet hitting these surfaces can rebound in 10 milliseconds—faster than a blink.<[silence:1200]> Used in pipes, they cut drag by 40%, saving energy.<[silence:2400]

Three related subjects are bio-inspired materials, fluid dynamics tricks, and anti-icing coatings.
